but for a swimmer, the secret of reducing skin/suit-friction drag is to maintain laminar flow, a condition where the fluid glides smoothly over the surface. Water in laminar flow behaves as if it was a sandwich of many sheets, each one sliding smoothly against its neighbour. The layer closest to the skin is pulled along nearly at the speed of the surface itself while the layer furthest away is hardly in motion. The entire sandwich of layers influenced by the surface itself is quite thin, but if it is in laminar flow, it provides lubrication allowing the body to slide through the water. It is very difficult to establish laminar flow. The slightest irregularity, a bump, sharp edge, or natural roughness is enough to spoil laminar flow and cause turbulent flow. Turbulent flow, in which water in contact with the skin or fabric swirls violently in a tangle of microscopic eddies, causes friction that robs the swimmer of speed, power, and efficiency. It is unlikely that the human body can attain laminar flow in all but a few minor places. For swimming efficiency, it is probably better to attempt to reduce turbulent flow that will result in better "sliding" through the water.

Hey, another great fun and interesting video! Just, laminar flows are not only a game. In aviation they're kind of a holy grail. As the airfoils in an aircraft wing are able to  drastically reduce the shape drag, ideally you want to have laminar flow to reduce the skin friction drag (in contrast to a golf ball where you need to reduce the shape drag). But as it was rightly said in the video, at the flight Reyonolds number of a large commercial airplane there's no chance to keep the boundary layer laminar along the wing chord. Much research has been done in this direction. Some airplanes though can do that, in fact they are specifically designed and built to achieve laminar flow over 60%+ of the upper and lower wing surfaces.... Fancy to know what kind of aircraft can do that? Those are the modern high performance gliders (see my channel), whose airfoils are spefically designed to delay the transition of the boundary layer as much aft as possible. Thanks to the laminar flow (and to therir high aspect ratio wings) modern gliders can fly with Lift to Drag ratios of over 50, which means for every mile of altitude loss the glider will fly a distance of 50+ miles. Laminar flows are amazing if you're a glider pilot :)

I'm an engineer and turbulence is just as important and "interesting" as laminar flow. For most things, laminar flow is very rare or short lived. I find it incredible that while we as a race spend billions to delve deep into the heart of sub-atomic particles and also the vastness of space, we pay relatively little attention to this thing we see every day! We are stuck using empirical, not analytical, models to estimate its properties! Btw when Derek said the Navier-Stokes equations are true for any fluid flow, he means any incompressible fluid (e.g. low speed air or water). He is totally correct about how hard thet are to solve analytically and neatly. A more general equation for fluid flow would be the Cauchy equations, which is true regardless of whether the flow is compressible or not. (In fact, the N-S equations drop very neatly out of the Cauchy equations if you assume the divergence of the velocity vector is zero.)

It seems worth noting that vortex generators slow planes down under most conditions.

They are relatively rare because they serve a very particular purpose: they help the plane generate more lift at high angles of attack. You only use a high angle of attack during certain high-performance maneuvers such as short field takeoffs or landings, or perhaps on planes which carry exceptional weight for their size such as air tractors.

For travel between major hubs (or even smaller regional airports) most planes omit the generators to save fuel in cruising flight. I'd say that's something other than fountains to put in the laminar column.

I have an issue when vortex generators are associated with producing turbulent air, this you demonstrated very well with water stating that the vortex is in fact laminar flow.  I have experimented a good bit with aerodynamics with both aircraft and automobiles.  A vortex generator creates a small tornado which in itself is a low pressure zone which by its nature tends to stick to the surface and causes the laminar flow to stick closer to the upper surface of the wing.  At lower speeds and therefore higher angles of attack this helps by creating more lift due to the tornadoes tendency to stick to the surface also by causing more airflow over the ailerons which makes the aircraft more controllable.  At higher speeds the aircraft can be flown with less angle of attack a produce less drag still maintaining level flight.  When vortex generators are installed properly the aircraft can fly slower and enjoy the benefit of slower stall speeds, better handling, higher to speed and/or lower fuel consumption.

Good video! Being nit-picky but the Navier-Stokes are discussed as being chaotically - deterministic - and the two aren't . Fundamentally, a number of turbulence models rely on stochastic approaches. Reynolds averaging relys on there being a mean component - which is deterministic. The instantaneous component will always be chaotic - but if there wasn't some deterministic properties then most of modern research into turbulence wouldn't hold.

The discussion with regards to the vortex generators is a bit incorrect as well. Vorticity isn't necessarily an exclusive property of turbulence, it happens in laminar flow as well. Your discussion on Von Karman sheets highlights this. In reality the shear in a vortex core will generate turbulence - as strain is one of the key mechanisms of turbulent production - but a VGs main role isn't to generate turbulence - just a by-product.

The Voyager around-the-world airplane NEEDED vortex generators to be safe to fly. The canard (front wing) was a laminar-flow airfoil that lost all its lift when raindrops clung to the surface. Vortex (turbulent air) generators scrubbed the raindrops off the canard's top surface, making Voyager safe to fly through rain.

The Cessna 177 aircraft was designed with a laminar-flow wing, and it works fine until you stall it. The stall entry gives zero warning and is very abrupt. Non-laminar wings give you some warning of incipient stall through buffeting. So yeah, turbulence rocks!

Super explanation, but there is a fundamental flaw in your story about aerodynamics of the vortex generators on top of wing. On a jet aircraft they are not there to delay stall due to a too slow speed and large angle of attack, but they are there to prevent stall due to a too high speed and prevent flow separation after a so called standing shock wave. In cruise flight the speed on top of the wing is above mach 1, and when further back on the wing the speed drops back to below the speed of sound it creates a shock wave which induces flow separation which we call shock stall. The vortex generators make very strong turbulent flow (that is correct) which reduces the flow separation due to the shock wave and consequently the aircraft can fly faster.

I learned from another video that vortex shedding is why tall skyscrapers are so wobbly. The super high speed of the wind at that altitude pouring around the barrier of a tall skinny building is what prompts the vortex shedding. The alternation of the vortices is what creates a sway back and forth. Some architects use wind passageways through the building so that wind can go through instead of around, which reduces the vortices. This creates a more comfortable environment for those on the upper floors (so they don't get motion sick when winds are high).

Laminar flow done right, such as boundary layer suction, allows high speeds and ultimate efficiency. It's just not being considered because aircraft manufacturers are not caring about this level of detail. It's been known since the 1960s to be possible to reduce drag to small fractions of what we currently pay for in today's "modern" designs.

You can still simulate and nicely predict where all the larger more relevant pressure vortex field distributions (energy and force direction) in total go. Laminar is the rare and beautiful exception. Sth that can still be done in an exam with a pocket calculator in minutes. That why exam question can be done w/o a computer and no one does want you to have a device capable to google and communicate in one. What if we solved how eddies work first. Where the higher pressure overtakes the lower pressure thereby creating eddies as low pressure approaches to zero. Speed and size are determined by fluid viscosity, and the area of where the low pressure is. In a hurricane, the speed is much faster at the center and slower at the sides. Then relationship between eddies depends on multiple points in an area of low pressure and how fast the initial velocity prior to the area where differences in low pressure are located. Shape would be determined by fluid pressure and speed levels around the eddy. Build a formula to scale it up and there you go, turbulence. Love the dead fish swimming upstream.  I love your content, but have to say, you didn't do a great job explaining why - even a dead fish - can swim upstream.  In the section where you describe periodic vortex shedding and the  von Kármán Vortex Street lies the answer.  You are way more knowledgeable than me, but you never discussed the high and low pressures created by laminar and turbulent flow.  For instance, you only discussed the turbulent flow over a wing, but not the laminar (like) flow underneath it thereby creating low and high pressure points or lift.  In water that horizontal like model is turned on its side.  During the periodic vortex shedding section you can see the low pressure areas created by the shedding and it's predictable as you describe.  My point, doesn't the fish sense the low pressure points of water rushing downstream and swims in them and avoids the more laminar like flow of the remaining water.  The von Kármán Vortex Street shown in the clouds shows the path a fish would take.  I think if you could produce a video of the dead fish swimming upstream with the florescent die you would see the fish transition from one vortex to the next - staying between them (maybe on a tangent with the vortex).   Again, in the portion where you introduce periodic vortex shedding you can see the path required to take to move upstream.  This could also explain why the fish seems to wiggle as his swims upstream in addition to the wiggle created by his tail.   Please let me know if my explanation is a beautiful as a laminar fountain, or as turbulent as your rheoscopic fluid tank.

Not having a personal preference for either, I work with laminar flow on a daily basis because of most of has been said about turbulent. In oil drilling, production and transport laminar is a must because causes less damage to piping, equipment and less deterioration to wellbores - and I expect for these same reasons any industry that depends on fluids transport via pumping will require their flows to be laminar, therefore laminar flow has a huge impact on industry, of which water fountains certainly is a tiny fraction.  

Laminar flow is also harder to achieve and maintain on larger scales just like you said, and yet it is done in conditions where up to 1200 gallons per minute or more in 17.5" tube sizes or larger are needed - that's why research to learn how to efficiently maintain fluids flowing in laminar regimes is very important. So where not really a big deal, I think it gets despised big time just because is not so visible - and also because it is just prettier.

Turbulent flow is simply laminar or stokes flow with an overall vector sum of zero. It has reached a threshold of velocity defined by the Du/Dt of the navier-stokes equation defined by the viscosity, and density of the fluid in question. Once Du/Dt has been achieved the easiest place for any additional energy, force, or acceleration to go will be applied to the vector's direction and perhaps some thermal expansion thus generating turbulence. With an ifr inside a turbulent system it would appear as if parts of the fluid are moving faster than Du/Dt however that is just a product of their direction of travel relative to one another and really they are only moving at Du/Dt in different directions resulting in a divergence with a value greater than Du/Dt.

With vortex generators it's also worth mentioning that they increase the local airspeed over the control surfaces, in this case ailerons. A spinning vortex is moving faster than separated, turbulent or laminar flow. Therefore, the force generated by the control surface is significantly larger (Bernoulli's principle, the V^2 term), thus you have more control of the aircraft. Particularly useful in stall conditions.
Source: I'm an MEng in Aeronautical Engineering (soon to be PhD)

"When I meet God, I am going to ask him two questions: Why relativity? And why turbulence? I really believe he will have an answer for the first."

I would add on the differences: Laminar - Linear,  Turbulence - Non-linear in both mathematical equation term and flow dynamics.

How is this confusing? A fluid has a binding property that makes the fluid particles near it behave similarly if the stress is low enough. When the stress gets to high, as in when different parts of the liquid that flows gets accelerated down to a lower velocity you get eddies.
From the perspective of the fast moving flow it is sliding against the surface of the slow moving flow, causing it to begin to roll. This is the same experience of the slow moving flow, it is rolled against the fast moving flow, but in the opposite direction.
First you get a kinked flow, which later kinks in to eddies.

In a sens there is always laminar flow, but segmented laminar flows that interact with each other forming stuff like Kelvin–Helmholtz instabilities.

There is an old simple pump that uses turbulent flow as power. Its most often called a "water widget". It works like the dead fish swimming up stream. Attached by a string up front, two small rectangles of wood joined by a hinge between them. A small set of 2, 1 way valves are mounted on one side. I thought the idea behind using miniature vortex generators (MVGs) and elongated roughness elements is that they produce streaks downstream which are less prone to turbulence transition. There has been a lot of work at KTH (Sweden) and at Imperial College London on this matter. The delay of transition is thought to greatly decrease the drag on such airplanes. Of course, MVGs are not useful during take off, landing, etc, but it is very likely useful during steady cruising.

I think using the golf ball as an example is misleading because the advantage of turbulent flow over laminar flow is only true in a "narrow" band of Reynolds numbers. At sufficiently high Reynolds numbers the drag coefficient is lower for the laminar flow.

Everyone talks about skin vs. pressure drag on golf balls. I think this subject needs an uplifting spin put on it. And I mean exactly that. Since you hit a golf ball with a wedge a lot of rotation is imparted on the ball with the lower edge traveling forward dragging (put intended) air with it. The air on the bottom of the ball is slowed down, relative to the ball, and the air on the top of the ball is sped up. This creates lift just like the sails on Jacques Cousteau's boat and much like an airplane wing. Thus, like a glider with wings that will travel farther than a ballistic glider that does not have wings, I propose that the dimples on a golf ball aid in creating lift which helps the ball travel further. They do this by increasing the skin friction drag so the spin of the ball is more efficient at creating lift than a smooth surface. Thus by adding drag the dimples help the ball travel further.

From a psychology standpoint, I wonder if laminar flow also appeals to us in part because it's on a much smaller scale than turbulent flow. We tend to be fascinated by things that go against our expectations, or that happen more rarely; not only is laminar flow very cool and kinda satisfying to look at because of the orderliness, but you also don't see it happen naturally very often, so it feels to us like a New Shiny Cool Thing, and that piques our curiosity, whereas turbulent flow is more like the cosmic norm, which makes it seem less interesting on the surface. Definitely far from boring though! I love how you can shed new light on seemingly ordinary things by zooming way out (or way in) and watching them work on different scales. I hadn't ever noticed how islands affect the clouds like that before! The universe is so cool, man.

As an aerospace engineer, this video was eye-candy.  It was nice to see Dustin hopping in as well.  From my point of view, laminar is not better than turbulent, nor vice-versa.  Both are useful.  Laminar flow is great for your airplane so that it has low drag (hence the development of laminar flow airfoils and nicely polished aluminium or composite surfaces instead of canvas ones).  Turbulent flow is great for your cars' radiators because the fluid get to move faster close to the radiator surface, thus increasing heat exchange.  Overall, the are both cool to study, but both have their place.

One of the points you did not cover is the momentum of the fluid in the laminar flow around objects. If I remember correctly as the velocity goes up, the boundary layer extends further away from the object. As size of the boundary layer also influences the pressure drag, it turns into too much of a good thing. You can say it increases the footprint of the object thereby increasing drag. Introducing turbulence generators at certain places, collapses the boundary layer and reduces pressure drag.

Also, the little tabs on the airplane wing introduces just enough turbulent flow to collapse the extended boundary layer just enough to still keep laminar flow over the aileron. So, not producing turbulent flow as such, just reducing the size of the laminar flow field. Let's face it, turbulent flow across the aileron is not a good thing; definitely not when I am in the plane.

A final point; turbulent flow might be great and interesting, but we need laminar flow to make our inventions work. Just like we need AC power to transport electricity, we still need to convert to DC to make your computer work.

One comment on the Vortex Generator (VG) stuff in the video, is that the flow has in fact already become turbulent long before it gets to the vortex generators. For higher angles of attack, which is where the VG's are effective, the flow boundary layer transitions to the turbulent state very close to the leading edge. The effect of the VG's is to re-energize the already turbulent boundary layer, which prevents separation (and the dangerous loss of lift that result from this). As long as the boundary layer is "energetic" enough, it does not separate. So the function of the VG's is simply to re-energize the already turbulent boundary layers, which delays separation. The result of this is that the lift can get higher (the airplane does not "fall out of the sky") than it would be able to without the VG's.
VG's are also used in other applications, such as on wind turbine blades. But in all cases they are used to re-energize already turbulent boundary layers.
The transition from a laminar to a turbulent boundary layer can be "forced" using small roughness elements, which are usually much smaller than VG's. Airplane gliders use specially made "zig-zag-tape"/turbulator-tape for this. This is typically 0.5mm high. This is enough to trip the boundary layer into the turbulent state.

Turbulent flow has it's place, but the most efficient aircraft feature laminar flow. The P-51 mustang performed so well in part because of it's laminar wing. Gliders all have laminar wings now.
And there are even experiments (by DLR) performed to use boundary layer suction to give the vertical stabilizer of an airliner laminar flow to save fuel. Airbus also has a A340 prototype with laminar outer wings.

The reason why large airplanes don't use laminar flow is because disturbed laminar flow causes more friction than turbulent flow, and regulations say you need to be prepared for the worst. So using a laminar wing, although probably more efficient, causes you to have to carry more fuel. This is because you might encounter flies on take-off and have to carry those the entire flight with you, with the high drag penalty as a result. To deal with this, researchers are looking into ways to shed the effected part of the wing (around the stagnation point) after take-off or fold it away.

The effect of disturbances is quite large. This is why competition gliders carry bug-wipers, devices to literally wipe the disturbances off the wing. The effect of a single fly on the front of a solar car in the Australian race is several minutes, if it was carried the entire way.

So laminar flow is actually much more efficient, but it's harder to maintain. If laminar flow is disturbed to turbulent uncontrolled, it causes more drag than flow that's turbulent from the start. That's why it's sometimes tripped with zig-zag tape (on gliders and ice-skating suits).

W.r.t. the golf balls, what's also interesting to me is how the dimples only work because of the speed at which golf balls happen to move at. At lower velocities (lower Reynold's numbers) there isn't much if any real difference between a dimpled and a smooth golf ball, and as velocity increases (Reynold's number goes up) the dimpled golf ball experiences a drop in drag coefficient. BUT if you'd increase the speed even further, a smooth golf ball would experience a similar drop, and the coefficient of drag would go even lower than with a dimpled ball, and significantly so. This is why golf ball dimples aren't really a solution for all kinds of applications. They depend on the scale, the velocity, and the balance/distribution between skin friction and pressure drag, among other things. For a golf ball these dimples increase skin friction, but the gains (at their usual velocities) from reduced pressure drag help more, but that doesn't hold true for e.g. planes.

I'm with Destin on this. Laminar Flow is a pocket of order in a sea of disorder. It's special, but importantly it's not so special that you don't get to touch it. Like many things, it's interesting because it's accessibly rare. It doesn't require multi-billion dollar labs in Europe to observe like antimatter, but it does require looking for it or putting in effort to create it.

Turbulent flow is more like dirt. It's found in some form just about everywhere, often overlooked, and vitally important for life. You will certainly find people who will argue this makes dirt more awesome, but I'll apply your "literally, definitionally" to "awesome" here.

We aren't in awe of things that are common, even if they do amazing things. Vanilla flavoring has embodied this reality so much that many people use "vanilla" to mean something is normal and uninteresting, almost an antonym of "awesome". And yet if you try something "vanilla flavored" without the vanilla flavoring, it's usually horrible. Things that are vital are generally common by necessity and design.

I forget who said it, but I've heard a physicist describe life as turbulence in the flow of entropy. And it's accurate to a degree, but what makes life special, like laminar flow, is our order. Living cells are pockets of "order" that produce a lot of "disorder" in their wake from the perspective of entropy.

I feel like turbulence is caused by friction and the changes in density caused by an object passing through whatever it is that is flowing turbulently. My theory is that it IS in fact predictable in a controlled environment when you have a set object following a set path through a set flow such as a wind tunnel and an object on a track. Thinking of how explosions work, something explodes, a lot of air and material are expelled, and then everything tries to rush back in and fill that void. It’s almost an elastic phenomenon from my perspective, which is why the dead fish flows up stream in the wake of an object, it’s riding the low pressure area and it’s shape helps it do that. I’ve always thought about this stuff and always noticed it but never occurred to me that it wasn’t predictable. Now you’ve got me thinking! Thanks for scratching my brain!

You mention reduced skin friction for a laminar boundary layer but what about the pressure/form drag? From the plot of Cd and Re, there is a Reynold's number range where the pressure drag dominates the skin friction drag and for that reason, a the turbulent boundary layer is preferred for it's lower pressure drag....which results from it's ability to withstand adverse pressure gradients. I feel like a distinction between the significance of pressure drag vs skin friction drag should have been made.

There are many phenomena in nature capable of extending over (almost) infinite orders of magnitude. In fact, every second order phase transition creates that: magnets at the Curie temperature, or fluids in their critical temperature (creating the "critical opalescence"). Actually, in 1987 a theory was proposed to describe complex systems in terms of critical phase transitions, since in complex systems you often observe quantities that extend over many scales. The theory is called "Self-Organized Criticality" (proposed by Bak, Tang and Wisenfeld). It's been a wide area of research over the last 30 years, and nowadays it's believed that the activity in the brain presents a sort of self-organization around (close to) the critical point. Other phenomena, such as solar flares, earthquakes, avalanches, etc, are also theoretically (and sometimes experimentally) shown to obey such laws of Self-Organized Criticality.

Turbulent flow is beautiful in its own way (still prefer laminar, as it lets my cleanrooms work 😉), and it's far more useful than I think people realize. For example, it helps monitor the health of our cardiovascular system.

Under ideal conditions (e.g., long, straight, smooth blood vessels), the critical Re (Reynold's Number) of blood is relatively high. However, in branching vessels, or in vessels with plaque protruding inward, the critical Re is much lower so that there can be turbulence even at normal physiological flow velocities. This turbulence generates sound waves (e.g., ejection murmurs, carotid bruits) that can be heard with a stethoscope. Because higher velocities enhance turbulence, murmurs intensify as flow increases. Elevated cardiac outputs, even across anatomically normal aortic valves, can cause murmurs because of turbulence. Murmurs are abnormal heart sounds that are heard using a stethoscope, and, while they can be harmless, they can also indicate an underlying condition -- anything from atherosclerosis to hypotension -- so the ability to hear them is just another way that doctors can catch problems before they kill us. Really awesome video, although I am not sold on the airplane wing demonstration. You showed how the airflow reacts to wings with and without vortex generators, but I don't believe you made the connection between attached airflow following the surface and lift. Intuitively, stall will happen the more perpendicular the wing is to the airflow which seems to be its own kind of turbulent flow (as evidenced by the strings going wild) - so, the vortex generators are using turbulent flow to solve a problem originally caused by turbulent flow in the first place. At any rate, it is unclear to me how having more attached airflow over the wing allows for maintaining lift. Or am I supposed to infer that having more attached airflow helps maintain lift because it cannot be pushing downward on the wing if it's following the surface? But doesn't some of the increased skin friction compared to laminar flow translate into downward force? Would it not be possible to design a wing that is more conducive to laminar flow when approaching the stall condition?

ok... there's a bit of misinformation here...
Technically, flushing [small] solids (i.e. wipes, napkins, paper towels, even small hand towels, etc) down the toilet is not what clogs the system. The systems were designed for this and more. Now, a diaper may clog it, as it is a little on the big side, but we're talking 4", 6", 8", and bigger diameter pipes here. The main thing that clogs pipes is cracks or roots in the pipe, or improper pipe laying. The test you did here about the paper breaking up is actually so if it got caught on a crack or root sticking in the pipe it would break apart and not block or catch more things "adding to it" until it's clogged. Instead of fixing the problem/pipes.

We're being urged by our wastewater treatment industry to not to flush 'flushable' wipes. Because they're technically flushable, but not wastewater system processable. It's always been a problem, but the pandemic has seen such an increase that they've launched campaigns about it.
When those wipes are down in the pipes, they don't have the benefit of 1) something strong trying to pull them apart such as a roll of coins while they're 2) stretched out flat. Rather they go down in a scrunched up clump and then proceed to get more clumped. Toilet paper breaks apart regardless, that's how much its structural integrity degrades. But the wipes stay intact until something acts to pull them apart so they make clumps that reinforce each other and create blockages in the treatment plant. So yeah, they flush, and don't block your residential pipes. But they cause havoc at the treatment plant.
I will agree with two points though. They're not as bad as flushing paper towels, and they're not as bad as flushing regular baby wipes.
Still shouldn't flush them though.

Turbulent flow is laminar flow that has changed direction for a reason.  Laminar air flow over an airplanes' wing becomes turbulent when it encounters an obstacle. Laminar flow in a river becomes turbulent when it encounters rocks,  and returns to laminar when the water passes the rocks.  In the atmosphere warm air and cold are laminar until they meet each other or a ground obstacle. When a cold front collides with a warm front thunderstorms and tornadoes occur.  Newtons law of motion can apply to air flow just as easily as it does to an object. Air and water will continue in a laminar fashion until an outside force, such as an obstacle or change in temperature, affects it. I wouldn't call turbulence unpredictable, a wind tunnel or float channel works well to predict turbulence.

Great presentation. Shockingly simple and astoundingly thought-provoking. If you think deeper about it, the apparently mutually conflicting cases (but obviously a case of gradual transitional boundary regions and variables) between laminar and turbular flows are everywhere, not just in physics but also in mathematics, social structures, epidemics and almost everything we see and experience in the universe. This has important implications. As they are all analogous, any solutions we find to a problem in one field can be adapted to another seemingly unattached field with much ease. We only need to identify the corresponding variables involved and a way to measure them quick and precise.

Fun fact about vortex shedding, when designing towers architects and engineers avoid a perfectly smooth facade or add exterior "fins" to a circular plan shape. The alternating eddies make the tower oscillate, and if at a certain windspeed the frequency of oscillation becomes equal to the resonant frequency of the tower the structure becomes likely to fail. An excellent example of this is the Burj khalifa's Plan designed to combat vortex shedding at such heights.

I don't understand why the defiition of turbulent flow has to be so complicated. Why can't anything above a certain Reynolds number be considered turbulent? I.e., why can't it just be that simple definition. All the other stuff you list is just properties of turbulent flow, not part of the definition.

What perplexes me is to consider what a Reynolds number would even mean for turbulent flow. One of the major properties of the turbulent flow is the varying speeds. Heck, that's even a trait of laminar flow. So in a pipe, with the innermost fluid flowing the fastest, and the outermost fluid flowing the slowest, it seems kind of arbitrary to me to simply refer to the "speed" of the fluid as if it were a single number.

But forget about that for a moment. What about with turbulent flow? Within each of those eddies, there are laminae. The flow within the Eddie is laminar (and bulk). What do we mean when we say the "velocity" of the fluid is such and such? I assume we mean bulk flow, but that's really arbitrary. There are countless velocities within those countless eddies.

It seems like it wouldn't be too hard to come up with a definition of turbulence (especially in an age of computers) where the Reynolds number (or a more sophisticated equivalent) could be considered for each cube within the eddy.

Edit: better breakup is good for a (public) sanitary sewer because pumps can move a slurry but might clog on with fibrous material. For septic, it's better that they don't break down. A broken-down fiber slurry will clog the effluent filter, resulting in more frequent pumping unless you clean the filter. It's not hard to clean it, and it's not really gross, but must people just call the pumper truck. If they don't break down, they just add to the floating mat or non-digestible matter which builds up much slower than it takes to start passing sludge / fiber slurry to the filter.

Lets not forget Smarter Every Day exploring turbulent flow with suppressor technology: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pOXunRYJIw

In the case of suppressors, (aka 'silencers') the bullet is intended to freely pass through holes in a tube with stacked baffles and not have its trajectory impeded by air pressure or currents. However the high-pressure gasses that follow need to be captured by the baffles to contain the blast and trap the gasses long enough for them to cool down, dissipating their energy before the gasses are slowly released. A good silencer must be made out of materials that can withstand high pressures and temperatures, and must have some degree of reducing the noise to hearing-safe levels. The technology has improved dramatically over the past decade, with new innovations in products like modular suppressors that can add or remove baffle sections to shorten or lengthen the overall dimensions, or 3D printed designs that can have internal volumes and geometries that would be impossible to manufacture with other means. There are even flow-through designs which try to reduce gasses that build up pressure and get directed back down the barrel into the weapon system (known as 'back pressure'). Suppressors are entirely reliant on containing the turbulence of gas expansion, but sometimes they use methods to direct gasses in specific directions.

It's true that the drag coefficient decreases dramatically for dimpled golf balls, but you don't see dimpled bullets. The reason for this is that there is a very strong velocity dependence which make the drag coefficient    different in different velocity regimes. At the speed of bullets a smooth surface has a lower drag coefficient; at the speed of golf balls a dimpled surface has a lower drag coefficient.

I work on human-powered-vehicles. The cutting edge of their aerodynamic design is in maintaining significant extents of laminar boundary layer over the surface then forming a critically steep trailing edge to obtain pressure recovery. The best designs can achieve almost 50% laminar flow on the vehicle surface and get CdA as small as 0.015 m^2. Doing things like this allow a cyclist to go up to 90 mph.
If you're interested in applications of laminar and turbulent boundary layers in experimental vehicle design, I recommend you talk to Calvin and Trefor at https://hpvdt.skule.ca/

Skin friction is why you can actually see higher flow through a muffler with perforations in a pipe that passes straight through it compared to a muffler with just a smooth straight pipe because of imperfections in the pipe wall causing a turbulent boundary layer.  Once the exhaust reaches a certain velocity, the skin friction on the non perforated pipe begins to cause too much turbulence and slows the flow of exhaust through the pipe.  With the perforations, it effectively creates a layer of gasses with 0 velocity, but it allows for a more laminar flow of the gasses closer towards the center of the pipe before you experience turbulence in that flow.  At least that's what some muffler manufacturers say.  The Mythbusters episode about the golf ball dimples on a car give weight to their argument.

The difference between laminar flow and turbulent flow is largely one of scale and energy.  Even in seemingly chaotic turbulence, if you zoom in to smaller scales, you will see laminar flow.  Case in point, the aquamarine tank he's swirling.  Similarly, even in seemingly smooth laminar flow, if you zoom out, you will see turbulence.  Case in point, when the laminar flow streams land in the fountain.

I am so glad to see this video. I wrote my doctoral dissertation on optical probes into turbulent systems. It turns out to be possible to see the Kolmogorov scale directly, without disturbing or decorating the flow using proper beam paths and correlation functions. I fell in love with the mathematical and physical complexity of turbulence a long time ago. It is the last great unsolved problem of classical physics and something we see over a vast range of scales and different systems from heliophysics to biophysics - not to mention it's impact on communications or any vehicle that goes in air or water.

In Norway we use the word krusning to describe slow moving turbulent flow. It means a wave or vortex that moves slowly while creating wonderfully turbulent patterns. Picture an ore dipping down in to the still water next to your boat. As you apply pressure to it, you create a krusning which, when the pressure is high enough, can even create small dimples in the water that form bubbles and splash a little as you pull the ore. This is the viking way of explaining turbulent flow. :)

<quote>

Turbulent flow doesn't make wings more efficient. It makes them much less so.
However, building laminar flow airfoils is difficult and dangerous because if designed around laminar flow wings an aircraft will not be able to fly if the flow becomes turbulent for any reason. And since there are thousands of reason flow can become turbulent (dust or dirt on the wing is enough) it is far more reliable (though much less energy efficient) to design a plane to fly with a turbulent flow airfoil.
Turbulent flow wings are BETTER for a lot of reasons, yes, but not more EFFICIENT.

You can find “awesomeness” with anything, common or rare.  You can say diamond is awesome, and you can say amorphous carbon is awesome.  Pointing to instances of “awesome” in order to prove a greater degree of “awesome” is very flawed.  You can point out more “awesome” things, but you can always point out more with the competing thing, then vice versa.  The response to “X is Awesome” isn’t “X is MORE Awesome” because that statement is meaningless.  A reasonable response would be “X is ALSO Awesome”, but frankly that doesn’t rake in nearly as many views.

Well, first of all; turbulence is not unpredictable. If you can justify throwing computers on top of computers to solve a problem, you can resolve length and time scales of turbulent structures/Kolmogorov scale, using Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS). This however, though, is very computationally expensive. As far as I know, there are no DNS solutions over an aircraft in cruise configuration; at high Reynolds number, due to low scales required. (please correct me if I'm wrong here!)
Also, high Reynolds numbers does not guarentee turbulence. By linear stability theory, there are 2 important Re values we need to consider, let's call them Re0 and Re1. Now, due to some effects (effects like noise, gust, geometry etc.)
there will be disturbances occuring inside the fluid. These distubances are not important until Re_cr, or equally, Re0. The waves are stable for sure below Re_cr. However, the waves get amplified after Re0.(possibly into Tollmien-Schlicting waves, then hairpin vortices and then fully turbulent spots if Re permits) Furthermore, the waves amplify until Re1 and then the waves are not amplified further. Now, the amplification ratio is A(remember that we do not know the value of initial disturbance but we can find the ratio), and ln(A) is generally taken as 9, which is a good estimate to obtain transition Re. (ln(A) is also known as n-factor). So, under right circumstances, there will be no transition even if you go insanely high Re.
Finally, there may be less pressure drag in turbulent flows, even though the skin friction coefficient (C_f) is higher, drag coefficient may be lower.

Since medical students and doctors might have learned that all blood flow is laminar, here is a correction. Generally in the body, blood flow is laminar. However, under conditions of high flow, particularly in the ascending aorta, laminar flow can be disrupted and become turbulent.
Under ideal conditions (e.g., long, straight, smooth blood vessels), the critical Re is relatively high. However, in branching vessels, or in vessels with atherosclerotic plaques protruding into the lumen, the critical Re is much lower so that there can be turbulence even at normal physiological flow velocities.

Erm... so.. Vortex Generators—
Aircraft mechanic and aerospace nerd here: A high Angle of Attack at a high speed might rip your wings clean off. You don't (typically) climb at a high AOA, although your pitch angle may be high, but that's relative to the ground. AOA is the wing chord relative to the air stream vector – a metric based on a reference frame fixed to the aircraft itself. Most controlled flight, (not including acrobatics or edge-of-the-envelope practice,) happens with a low angle of attack, and in those periods, vortex generators don't do anything useful. They don't aid efficiency – they add drag after all.
A high AOA happens in low-speed maneuvers, the most common being landing. If you can sustain lift at a higher AOA, thanks to adding VGs on the same aircraft, you can reduce the landing speed by quite a bit. Business jets tend to be very slipery, and without the VG's on the wing they would land at even higher speeds, requiring longer runways, increasing wear on the gear and brakes, and increasing the hazards of the landing process (like stability if the air is... well... too turbulent at landing.)
Keeping flow attached at high AOAs also helps the ailerons to do their job, since they're at the back edge where flow separates first, and this helps the pilot keep the wings level at touchdown. Er.. even moreso in... Turbulent Conditions. 😀
One might climb very steeply, at a high angle of attack and low forward speed, in order to surmount an obstacle, such as taking off from a tiny valley airstrip in the mountains and trying to get over the mountain pass ahead of you. But as soon as the plane levels off a bit and picks up speed, the horizontal stabilizer (I'm ignoring pilot input, trim, etc.) will weather-vane the aircraft into the "relative wind", bringing the AOA down closer to the chord line again. VGs are useful in the same regimes where extended flaps are useful, and VGs enhance the effectiveness of flaps too.
Just... VGs don't enhance efficiency.

Why do you check the turbulent flow as dissipative? Whereas the reynolds number is precisely the ratio between inertial forces (ρu) and viscous forces(ν), and the bigger this viscous dissipative term, more laminar is the flow.
In a laminar flow, the viscous forces are so high that the swirls do not even form, and any relative movement (∇²v) is rapidly attenuated by these dissipative forces, leaving us almost only with those of the boundary layer, as a simple consequence of minimizing the velocity gradient.
A turbulent flow is exactly the opposite, when inertial forces are high relative to viscous forces, so that the fluid keeps moving in any directions it can.
I can say that the reynolds number is a measure of how dissipative a flow is, and being not dissipative (in relation to inertia) is one definition of a turbulent flow.

6:12 "Laminar flow only occurs at low Reynolds numbers" No, that's not quite right. Below 2300, the flow will stabilize towards laminar. But even at high Reynolds numbers, the flow can be laminar, it's just super unstable that way. Like an inverted pendulum. There used to be an informal contest between physics students on who could get the highest Reynolds number laminar flow. Very careful setups with sand and clever valves and vibration isolation, etc. So, laminar flow can occur at high Reynolds numbers. But not without trying really hard.

Vortex generators have always been explained differently to me. Flow separation comes from the airflow velocity being too high (inertial forces too high) which overcome the viscous forces. Therefore, vortex generators diffuse the laminar velocity vectors of the airflow, decreasing the focused airstream velocity, That way the viscous forces can take over and keep the boundary layer tight to the wing surface. So, opposite of what is explained in the video. I have been building model sailplanes for years and this definition has always accurately described what I experience in real-world aerodynamic applications.

Now, consider that turbulent flow can actually be laminar, from the reference frame of a small enough object moving fast enough through the fluid. The turbulent currents will be too weak compared to the relative laminar stream, so you could say that laminar flow (and its awesomeness) is literally a matter of perspective.

Those vortex generators back of the leading edge of an airplane's wing actually make the downstream flow
LESS turbulent by making the flow less chaotic and more organized into regularly spaced vortices which
extend back almost the full span of the wing. Those horizontal tornado-like structures act like flowing "ropes"
of air that don't break up to put a static pressure on the top of the wing as turbulence would, but instead they
keep the flow organized and having their own continuously flowing mass and velocity, thereby preserving the
lowered pressure atop the wing - i.e. preserving "lift".

You should talk a bit about Formula 1 cars and how they handle turbulence generated by the cars, especially the front tires.  They use vortices shed by wings in the front of the car to form a boundary layer of turbulent air around the car that clean air can flow over with less drag.  Everything about aerodynamics in automotive racing is like this, but Formula 1 is especially advanced in its understanding of how to make the air go around the car in the most efficient manner.  It's really interesting.  Of course, I'm just an amateur that's interested in it, and it's been a while since I've done any learning about it, so I'm sure my  description is wrong in some way and overly simplistic, but it's still a very interesting subject to learn about.

With a lot of the design work I have done, it was always nice when the Reynolds number was calculated for you - when the software was built correctly :-)

For example all the engineering data for ground Source heat pumps, it would have the data for water, propylene glycol and methanol and it would calculate the specific gravity for you when you entered how much freeze protection was needed. So once the pipe sizing and all that was entered oh, it was spit out a Reynolds number and you would want it to be over 2000. Getting turbulent flow with propylene glycol mixed with water is somewhat difficult without a lot of pumping power, but since the pipe of choice is high-density polyethylene and me being me, I got some clear plastic pipe and temporarily put it into a section on a system I had designed and had a variable speed pump and I was pretty impressed with how accurate software was that I had my fingertips and was free, I think it still is :-)

I'm not a scientist, so please forgive me if I use incorrect terminology. But I think I might be able to articulate my thoughts well enough for the concept (of my idea) to be undersood.

Turbulent and laminar flow are two sides of the same coin. The main difference is in their respective energy states and the number of interactions after/during disturbance. Increase the number of interactions, or the amount of energy exchange during the interaction, and you increase the turbulence.

Predicting turbulence is possible to a degree, but you would have to know:

a) the composition/geometry of the materials involved; b) the molecular positioning of all involved materials; c) the energy states; d) the direction/composition/energy/duration of the disturbing entity.

The problem is, in certain conditions, I imagine even quantum fluctuations can have an impact on the results. Even if you were able to measure everything to such a minute level, keeping track of each item, knowing how each interactions with another, and performing the necessary equations to predict the next stage of interactions, you would need to perform this equation billions upon billions of times simultaneously and instantaneously. We are not omniscient.

Maybe in a controlled situation where you have a pure fluid, that only reacts by way of kinetic energy but this interaction doesn't alter the fluid in any other way besides temperate and movement. It resides in a well understood and measured container, and is subjected to a short, well measured and understood sound wave. If you already know how the fluid behaves when subjected to sound, you could predict the interactions and state when,and for how long there will be turbulence. You could even extrapolate the movent patterns if the sounds were to be continuous. But again, there would come a point where the calculations required would become astronomical. Like trying to find the end of Pi. 🤫 Maybe Pi has the answer?
Maybe all I've done here is illustrate the difficulty in attempting to accurately predict turbulence. Some things are just not meant to be known in such a precise manner.

You also need turbulent flow in hydronic heating systems. You will not get adequate heat transfer from the water to the pipe and into the room if you do not design the pumping/piping system such that turbulent flow in the pipes is achieved. If the flow is laminar, the laminar boundary layer acts as an insulator of sorts, with the hot water flowing past in the center of the pipe and not giving off its heat to the pipe/fins.

So is turbulent flow chaos theory? This seems like the same math as the logistics map. Going off the Reynolds's experiment: with the flow rate (growth rate) being the most important factor. The pipe width and viscosity of fluid are the initial conditions (initial population) and they don't really matter that much since its the flow rate that ultimately causes the turbulence. The video was pretty nice. However, I had some thoughts about the part where you said that the flow on surface of sun is turbulent. You see laminar and turbulent are terms that are usually applied to "fluids" which are gases and liquids. Surface of sun on the other hand, consists of plasma, the so called fourth state of matter. One may argue that plasma is nothing but super hot gas, and hence a fluid, so you can still use the terms laminar and turbulent but consider this : fluid particles at normal temperatures have much smaller energy when compared to the super hot plasma particles. The energy in plasma is so high that atoms break into nuclei and electrons. So you can control the viscosity of normal temperature fluids by controlling their temperature but plasmas, they form only on high energies and hence by default have high "viscosity".

Nice to see how you argue with Destin. Both of you were right, both of you can agree to each other and both of you can disagree, which creates a wonderful dynamic and makes the whole material far more interesting.
Years ago, in Poland, a TV scientific program was shown, where two talented mans, Andrzej Kurek and Zdzislaw Kaminski presented the newest achievements in science and technology. This was so far, in my experience the best program in the world (far better than current Discovery channels). They presented different points of view, they discussed, argued in a very interesting way, showing sometimes opposite points of view. They died in car accident, and since then, no better program of such value was even made. BUT! Your short conversation with Destin showed the same dynamic, and brang lot's of joy to the subject. I think that if you are interested in spreading and gaining attention to the channel, you can try to prepare more such scenarios, where not only you are interviewing somebody, but also you can argue with somebody, presenting things which are not as clear and one-dimensional as it seems. I know that your channel and production is set in a bit different mood, because you are presenting the truth, the simple, yet beautiful physical world, and they - in Polish TV presented achievements of technology (which is different), but still, if you find somebody who has a bit different point of view, you can not only as that person but also take a stand where you know something, which is certain, and he/she knows something which is certain, and if those points of view, or discoveries contradicts themselves, you will have an astounding material, which also can generate lot's of comments and even go viral. Remember those balls? It was not about science, it was about technology. What if you find somebody to argue that this was actually a bad idea? We all know that technology has its dark side too, like the environmental impact, etc. So many areas to cover! :) So many opportunities! :) I would love to see what is THE TRUTH about nuclear energy, what the heck is true with the 'green' energy, etc. Anyway, good luck, I love your productions, and I think Discovery and other semi-scientific channels can learn a lot from you!

Those flows you call laminar are not laminar at all. They look laminar, but they are clearly not, the Reynolds number is rather high. It is easy to mistake turbulence with its effects. We don't see air or water turbulence unless it is extremely high or we have some tracers or special visualisation techniques. Plus, the frozen effect of some jets has more to do with light and frame rights of the cameras than with turbulence.

12:44 - This phenomenon of the reduction in drag at higher speeds was shocking when first discovered. If you think about it, it's pretty crazy that something will get less drag when it gets faster! Imagine being pushed back by a strong wind, then suddenly it becomes a giant gale but it's actually easier to move through! The phenomenon also has the cool title of 'The Drag Crisis'.
As a bit of fun history, it was Gustave Eiffel - designer of the famous Eiffel Tower in France - who discovered this phenomenon. He was a prolific experimentalist and had one of the first wind tunnels (like those shown for the experiments here) installed under the tower. What's more he used to drop balls of different sizes from the tower and measure their time to hit the ground in order to calculate their drag. Unlike Galileo and his similar experiment on the Tower of Pisa, Eiffel was looking for the effect of wind resistance/drag not for the constancy of gravity.

The design of the golf ball is very impressive, but there are other ways to improve the boundary layer than triggering it to turbulence. One that I particularly like is to suck the low momentum particles next to the wall THROUGH the wall (using a porous wall like a sponge). The fast (high momentum) particles from the free-stream then take its place, preventing separation. It's an old idea, and some prototype planes were designed with wings that did this during WWII to get the edge over enemy air forces. In the end, simplicity won out, and the moving flap took the winning place for controlling the flow over a wing. This stimulates the boundary layer over the wing by redirecting high momentum air from under the wing over the boundary layer, allowing the plane to take steeper angles of attack. 'Boundary layer suction' as its called has since been relegated as a 'cool idea that isn't worthwhile' since then. But thanks to modern simulation software we can find ways to use suction more effectively to get much greater effects.

This is what my PhD research is on, and you can see a video with some simulations on my channel if you're interested (though the production value is MUCH lower than Veritasium) and, alas, the flow is laminar! https://youtu.be/jX7N_si5TwE

Having worked on turbulent and laminar flow on my PhD in CFD I believe that there isn’t a lot of future in turbulent flow. Yes it is more common than laminar flow, but it seems like with more advanced computers any turbulent flow will be able to be addressed as a summation of many more and much smaller laminar flows, giving us a better approximation than the ones of the existing models. This has happened in many complex phenomena and I believe it won’t take long to be the case for the study of turbulent flow as well.
Just out of curiosity: What will not be possible in the world or universe if Turbulent flow didn't exist?

(A) Less than 1 (I.e. Most of the energy generated by the turbines would have been wasted by the cars anyway... So installing them has a net benefit in terms of operating energy)
(B) About 1 (Turbines are stealing energy with no net benefit)
(C) Greater than 1 (Not only are the turbines increasing drag, they are converting the energy they steal inefficiently, resulting in a net loss of useful energy overall).

Can't say I agree to the premise of the video.  The real place of interest (and what's even more awesome to me) is just right at that transition from laminar to turbulent.  Think about it like this - laminar flow is very much a non-chaotic regime, while turbulent flow is the definition of a chaotic regime.  So, right at the border, where it's a muddled situation - yeah, that's where the real fun happens.  In general, researching boundary conditions is where a good chunk of new insights come from.  And yes, that's why black holes are so fascinating!

Oh god how much do i disagree with this video... First of all, people might understand something very wrong from what he says here... Yes the blood coming out of the aorta is turbulent, but the very essence of nornal blood dynamics is that it HAS to flow in a laminar manner, since turbulent blood flow causes many troubles. People with high blood pressure basically have problems with their blood vessels, either due to them being incompliant or atherosclerotic, and THAT causes turbulent flow and thus many health problems later on. Atrial fibrillation in the heart causes turbulent blood flow, and that changes the dynamics of the blood and may cause thrombosis and CVA... And besides, since laminar flow is the exception by actually 'opposing' to the number one rule in chemistry (the one that says the atrophy in the system has to grow no matter what happens), you have to respect laminar flow when you see it. In other words, turbulent flow is much more prevalent than laminar flow, and you don't have to make any effort for it to happen... But laminar flow is difficult to achieve, and it basically symbolizes the mind winning over chaos. So... Respect laminar flow! :-)

I got to the point where they guy started talking about his work in turbulant flow in rocket engines. Now, we all remember that there is a problem where you can created an engine where the fuel doesn't burn properly, and that zone moves from one part of the nozle to the other. In my mind, this is guttering, like you can see with a candle-flame or water coming out of a pipe. Possibly by that same mechanism that produces those streets whose name I can't remember right now.
They solved it by putting little ridges into where the fuel was being burned, so that if a non-fully-burned cell developed, it wouldn't move very far.
Seeing as turbulance mixes things, it strikes me that maybe that's what the ridges do. Instead of making sure those cells don't move, but rather they increaced the amount of turbulance and thus stopped the cells from being created in the first place.

Wow, you put a dumb salmon in there, and completely miss dolphins riding waves, or even waves in general... There's a section behind and under the curl of a wave that you can ride with little energy output. As the wave and water particles move forward, energy is funneled between the air above, and the surface below. A barrel is formed when this energy is funneled more precisely as it hits a reef for instance. This barrel exhibits both turbulent and laminar flow. Under and behind the barrel is a low pressure system with slow moving water. Completely under, the energy is forced out of line by the reef, and up and around this low pressure system. With nowhere else to go, besides being chaotic and turbulent, and moves over the low pressure system, in a line, to form the lip of a barrel, creating laminar flow. This laminar flow feeds back into the chaotic turbulent flow. So with enough energy, this creates a feedback loop, which creates the most gnarly, rideable barrels, that only require you to paddle into. To paddle into it, you use the low pressure system or a mini Eddy... Even crazier is that the air above creates a similar effect which looks like a ying yang symbol.
Long live laminar!

I work with kids that have behavioral and attention issues. In my research, and experience, turbulent flow objects can help refocus the mind in these kids (and in myself, because I also have trouble with the same problems). I have a craft project I do with the kids making Glitter Jars. A thumb width deep layer of clear glue,  warm water and a few tablespoons of various weights and colors of glitter go into a 1 quart Mason jar. Whenever the student (or myself) get too distracted, a few shakes of the jar and then you are given a few minutes of watching the glitter settle. Not sure how this translates into refocusing the mind, but it works wonders! I see a lot of the same patterns in my jar that were shown in this video. Turbulent flow IN ACTION!

Have you ever heard of the Kline Fogleman airfoil? It introduces a step or discontinuity on the surface of an airfoil which traps a vortex of displaced air which becomes part of the airfoil. This causes a delay in the stall up to 45 degrees. The aircraft handles high winds much better and is extremely stable. The concept has been used in scratch built radio controlled aircraft for over ten years. There are many videos on youtube which show KF airfoils in action. Also, check out Wikipedia as well. Just thought you might be interested. Many papers have been presented with positive results from India to Korea to Canada. Still, the world resists ideas that go against the grain. It’s par for the course.

chaotic flow is different from turbulent flow.
Laminar flow is not limited to low velocity, small sizes and viscous fluids. It's limited to low Reynolds Numbers.
If the case in point is a circular pipe, the value of Reynolds number needs to be below about 2100 in order to maintain laminar flow conditions. (it also assumes that fully developed flow conditions have been attained).
In other words you can double the diameter of circular pipe and reduce the mean velocity by half and the Reynolds number will not change assuming the viscosity and density is the same. (Re = Dνρ/μ - dont forget that density is also a variable in Reynolds Number. Re does not equal vL/viscosity as shown in this video. Reynolds Number, is a dimensionless quantity so there are no units for the values you obtain. Cant leave out the density term, even if it's assumed to be constant).
Although Particle Reynolds Number is still a ratio of the inertial to viscous forces in a flow system, the value for D (or L) is not the size of the container but rather the diameter of the particles.
The example of the smoke stream emanating from a candle is a good case in point. The reason the smoke particles are initially in a nice neat column and then spreading out into turbulent-like curls much higher up from the candle flame is dues to the initial temperature difference between the candle fumes and the surrounding air and the fact that thermal equilibrium conditions are eventually reached higher up.
Referring to Reynolds Number without providing a clear outline of what the parameters refer to can be misleading.
The stream that flows from a candle flame initially cannot be assumed to be laminar merely because it appears as near uniform tube-like flow. Within the stream the fine particles are moving in a turbulent like behaviour. They are not flowing upwards in laminar sheets with linear velocities that never move across the flow. Very close to the candle wick there will be a flow regime that will be laminar in nature. And also at the boundary between the upward flowing column and the surrounding air there will be special flow conditions. This is not a good example of laminar flow transitioning to turbulent flow if you look deeper. Imagine lighting the same candle in the same Laboratory environment but increasing the air temperature? That is, the fumes are rising in very hot air rather than the room temperature air. Or indeed you can decrease the ambient air temperature to near freezing. Do you think that the length of the column and the behaviour of the "spread out" turbulent region higher up will change with different ambient air temperatures.
One way to demonstrate laminar and turbulent flow is to set up an experiment with a transparent pipe that introduces a dye withing the flow regime. Observe the behaviour of the dye stream within the flow as you increase the flow rate.

Dead fish do not swim upstream. Water "pillows" on the upstream side of an obstruction, as it flows around the object.  Behind the obstruction, water reverses flow and flows upstream creating what is called an eddy, or reversal in white water parlance. Such a reversal can create a "hole" because water actually flows down behind the obstruction creating a lower water level inside the eddy.

The thing I find most fascinating about periodic vortex shedding is how turned out to be a problem when we started building high chimnies during the industrial revolution. You would sometimes see these chimnies start swinging back and forth until they eventually broke apart. What turned out to be happening was that if the wind blew with precisely the right speed, mind you this doesn't need to be particularly fast, you would end up with periodic vortex shedding that resonated with the chimney and induced more and more energy into the system. As a result, modern chimnies are often built with "fins" on their sides to make the air flowing around the right and left sides not meet up on the other side, eliminating the effect.

) Falun Gong practitioners in Germany held a Falun Gong Information Day in downtown Stuttgart on May 30, 2020, to introduce Falun Gong and expose the persecution of innocent practitioners by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).


Falun Gong practitioners demonstrate the exercises.

Stuttgart is the capital of southwest Germany’s Baden-Württemberg state and a famous manufacturing hub. Mercedes-Benz, Porsche, Bosch, SAP Software Solutions and other world famous companies have their headquarters there. During the coronavirus pandemic, the city was hit hard and the number of people infected in Stuttgart ranked third in Germany.

As Germany has now reopened, Falun Gong practitioners held their first Information Day on the busiest street in Stuttgart, Königstraße. Many people watched practitioners demonstrate the Falun Gong exercises to the beautiful music.

A young woman carefully followed along with the practitioners' exercise movements during the exercise demonstration. She took an introductory flyer afterward and said she planned to read more about Falun Gong online.

A young man picked up an introductory flyer for his friend who likes meditation. Another young man talked with a practitioner for a long time and said he was interested in learning Falun Gong. He was familiar with terms like De (virtue) and karma, because one of his friends had spent six years in a Chinese temple.

A middle-aged woman said she would like to learn Falun Gong. She was happy to know that Falun Gong exercise instruction is always free. She took information about a local group-exercise site and said she planned to attend.

A woman asked a practitioner why the CCP persecutes Falun Gong. The practitioner explained how Falun Gong’s principles of Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance oppose the CCP’s wicked ideology of struggling against fellow man and nature. The practitioner also explained how the CCP had fabricated lies to smear Falun Gong to turn the populace against practitioners, and how it had used the same tactics of deception with the coronavirus pandemic. The woman agreed with the practitioner.

About the ad at the end.. I’ve worked in a maintenance department at a hospital for 5 years and the the biggest headaches I ever had were sewage blockages because “flushable wipes” had clogged the main line. Our department finally convinced upper management to tell the employees to throw them away instead of flushing them, and the issue went away almost immediately. After that, if we had sewage issues we would usually find out people had been using them again. That roll of pennies might have fell through that wipe, but they do not Disintegrate like toilet paper does! Have you ever tried to wipe something with wet toilet paper? No, because you’ll end up having to wipe it off too. I’m not mad about the ad, wipes can be thrown away instead; I just want to point out that flushing them could potentially cause issues regardless if a quarter pound of pennies can fall through it. There are a ton of articles online about the topic, I encourage you do your own research.

One of the interpretations of the Reynolds number that really helped me grasp the concept of turbulent flow is that it is the ratio of kinetic forces to friction forces.
- A high Reynolds number means that the flow is governed by its inertia hence its chaotic movement
- Laminar flows, with lower Reynolds number are governed by friction forces (as they have a relatively lower inertia), hence their predictability and smooth movement

As a mechanical engineer, I remember fluid mechanics being simultaneously one of the hardest to understand, and easiest to pass classes in undergraduate. It was an odd feeling getting my grades back at the end of the semester and discovering I had gotten one of my highest grades in my entire college career in a class that I felt so bewildered by. The class was this weird mixture of struggling to understand these extremely complicated equations like Navier-Stokes, and these really "hand wavy" methods like dimensional analysis.

I always thought my grade came down to being rescued by a generous curve and the Professor just wasn't teaching the class well, but videos like this definitely make me reconsider how difficult it must be to make fluid mechanics accessible to an undergraduate level class. The math behind the physics is so complicated that you basically have to study it empirically in a case-by-case basis, which doesn't really work in a lecture hall with 100+ students.
We studied fluid mechanics as two parts in two semesters in Civil Engineering, I can honestly say this video covers one whole semester minus in depth mathematics involved. Noice.

Minor insignificant correction from a student pilot/aerospace engineering student: angle of attack has everything to do with airspeed and not just vertical speed. You actually climb faster at a shallower angle of attack than the max you can safely fly. As I'm sure you're aware, as you lose airspeed, the pressure differential across the wing is reduced. The angle of attack is increased until the momentum of the air impacting on the bottom of the wing is sufficient to augment the total lift. The angle of attack thing is important for landing, when you want to be flying as slow as is safe, and anytime you are doing steep turns where you partially force air at the wing from the bottom due to your inertia through the turn.

Obviously this doesn't matter in the context of this video, just wanted to offer information about a narrative comment Derek made in the video.

It depends on the application as to which is better. I used to build high performance engines for various motorsport applications. When it comes to air flowing through an engine, turbulent flow is better because if the air to to smooth and laminar then the surface tension is higher and the air tends to be more "sticky" if you will. Clinging to the inside surfaces of the intake runners and slowing down. You need to break that air up so i can flow more freely. The opposite is true in an engine when it comes to liquids. When it comes to liquids like fuel and oil Laminar flow is better. Turbulent flow in a liquid can cause cavitation and aeration and when you are talking fuel, this will decrease the energy output per volume as the fuel becomes less dense. And with oil aeration can cause it to become less sticky and loose lubricating properties. and in hydraulic fluids like transmissions and power steering aeration means the fluid can now be compressed more then it could before, and again, you loose your ability to transfer energy through that fluid.  Also in the boating world the body of water your boat is riding on, actually works better if it's turbulent. Again if it's calm and laminar it has a greater surface area and surface tension, the boat tends to stick to it more. This creates more drag and less efficiently. But if you can break that water up and aerate it as it rushes under the hull, you'll both be able to go faster and have greater efficiency. By breaking up that surface tension you also break up the drag. So like i said. Depends on the application as to which is best. :)

Whitewater kayakers use these principals all the time to travel upstream efficiently in not only obvious eddy currents behind rocks out of the water, but also in the turbulence moving downstream that is behind submerged rocks and waterfalls! Similarly, when kayaking across a large flat body of water like a lake, it is always faster to paddle around the perimeter if you have a headwind (the shores rob the wind of velocity) and to paddle down the middle with a tailwind! Laminar is cool, but without turbulence, kayaking would be boring!

Laminar motion is preferred for engineering purposes. Anytime we need to tame nature and create our order within that chaos, we certainly prefer for the fluid motion to be regular and consistent. Of course, you can cherry pick and find the instances where we might tame turbulent vortices to guarantee better control. But as far as I can tell, turbulence works against us more often than not.

Take the case of nuclear fusion reactors. Turbulent transport of particles and heat is a huge problem which leads to an excessive loss of energy and confined matter. Turbulence is probably the reason we will never be able to achieve a nuclear fusion reactor with hot plasma.

This guy is simply trying to be interesting by saying “turbulent flow is greater than laminar flow!”. No dude, it’s simply one regime of fluid mechanics and there is no “better” here. Laminar motion has been well explained for years now and it’s quite impressive what we have done with that knowledge. In fact, planes are a result of that. How do you think the theory of airfoils came about?

I’ve studied turbulence for years now. It’s the longest unsolved problem in classical mechanics and it’s been a huge barrier to things like nuclear fusion. It’s an extremely beautiful phenomenon but incredibly difficult to study from a physics perspective and very frustrating from an engineering perspective. This guy is batting out of his league because at least that other guy that he rags on has actually engineered and built things!

Has this guy actually put in the time to study turbulence theory? Has he worked with laminar flow to actually engineer something? My guess is not. Because if he did, he would appreciate the whole range of Reynolds numbers and would not act better than all of the accumulated knowledge about fluid mechanics that we currently have. From a scientific perspective, it’s frustrating to see people like this.

This is reminding me of an experiment I had conducted during an internship where we used particle image velocimetry to visualize the fluid interaction between water and a robotic fish fin in effort to learn how we could improve our design to make a more efficient bio-inspired fin based vehicle. Even with a relatively low Reynolds numbers there was some vortex shedding off of the fin tips which was really fascinating to be able to visualize experimentally. Also, I remember learning the Navier-Stokes equations and having to solve simplified versions in my fluid dynamics class and can confirm that they are a pain to solve. Laminar flow is pretty, but turbulent flow is the flow regime that most of the universe operates in, with the whole second law of thermodynamics thing suggesting that everything tends to flow towards chaos. Also how flow will typically be laminar for some entry length in a tube, but given enough length it will tend to go turbulent since no tube is perfectly smooth. Anyways, I enjoyed the video and enjoy seeing people spread the fascinating world of fluid dynamics around.

Great Video! At 11:44 you mentioned “climbing at higher angles of attack”. Unfortunately, that’s not really true. Angle of Attack and the flight path the airplane takes through the air are two totally separate angles. They are related but that gets into weight, power, and airspeed. If airplanes were limited to climb at their maximum AoA, airplanes like the F22 would never be able to go straight up. Instead, ability to fly at higher Angles of Attack allows you to fly slower and pull more g’s when doing high speed aerobatics; great capabilities pilots like to have!

I must protest a tiny bit :) Laminar flow is NOT superficial nor a toy! A friend of mine is doing reaserch on rain formation in clouds and one of key factors is analysis of droplets interaction mediated by a laminar flow - of course they also use turbulence on a much greater scale but laminar flow is super important on a scale of interactions between droplets where Reynolds number is vanishing. Not to mention other parts of Re=0 fluids which are very important for medicine and biology (internals of cells for example) and are still poorly understood. Also the need of microswimming robots is all rooted in laminar flow physics. Laminar flow also presents a DETERMINISTIC CHAOS - for a simplest example it is enough to consider 3 spheres falling in a cylinder. You can never repeat experiment to get same trajectories. But I also agree that turbulent flow is awesome! Is it more awesome then laminar? For me yes, but still laminar is a super important case of a flow which is crucial for everyday life - from internals of our cells through lakes, rivers and oceans up to cloud / rain formation and other even more distanced phenomena.
