Fun fact about blood flow turbulence and that boundary layer issue. In a past job, we discovered that the rate of plaque build up in blood vessels was more likely when flow was more laminar. So, we developed a helical stent (stents are usually straight) for insertion into the artery to clear the plaque. This induced higher "skin friction" through turbulent flow. This reduced the rate of plaque reformation and the helical stent also helped the stent survive in more demanding compressive locations like the femoral artery. Super cool design.

comment_text: I would suggest that you read the study of Hof et al (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15361619/?dopt=Citation) that proved that pipe flow turbulence has underlying order that can be described ----at least in theory----using mathematical equations. The study also demonstrated that pipe flow resistance is the sole source of pipe flow resistance, and explained the nature of blood pressure, and the Bernoulli Principle. This is the essence of the new science of "Chaos" that is explained in a book of the same name by James Glieck, who was the science editor of the Wall Street Journal. True laminar pipe flow is virtually non-existent in familiar "Newtonian" fluids such as water, gasoline, steam, and atmospheric gases. Your examples merely illustrate situations where levels of pipe flow turbulence are very low; if you were to double the flow rate of the water in your examples you would observe exponential increases in turbulence that would inhibit flow rates and exaggerate lateral forces in the delivering pipe. True laminar pipe flow mostly exists in "non-Newtonian" fluids which consist of particulates suspended in the fluid that inhibit the formation of turbulent flow patterns when the fluid is accelerated. Mammalian blood is an obvious example of such a non-Newtonian fluid. The morphology and neutral bouyancy of mammalian red blood cells causes them to spontaneously form "aggregates" or "Roleaux" formations when blood is accelerated, and these formations prevent the formation of turbulent flow patterns. This is the secret of superior mammalian exercise tolerance as compared to other classes of vertebrates. The mammalian heart is able to eject its contents into the aorta in less than a tenth of a second because its red cells abolish turbulent flow resistance, so that mammalian blood flow is truly "laminar." The faster that blood is accelerated in arteries (or pipes) the lower its flow resistance. In contrast, the red cells of poikilothermc amphibians, turtles, and reptiles are much larger and are evolved to exaggerate systolic turbulence to prevent atherosclerosis at ambient temperatures below 100 degrees Fahrenheit, where blood lipoproteins become solid particulates and deposit on the interior walls of arteries and cause atherosclerosis. The Hof study has essentially refuted the Hagen-Pouiessele equation, the notion of "shear stress" and other such antiquated assumptions. www.stressmechanism.com

Chaos rules. Did you know hang gliders fly at transitional Reynolds #s. The quasi space of turbulence, but not. And because of this they can do things you might not think of. Like increase span efficency with roll and seem to be able drop below flying speed in lift. Now part of that former is the relatively poor span efficiency of swept flying wings with 20 deg of twist and relative reduction of span (to gravity vector) with roll. But, when looking at the lift produced by the mid-span sections and positive incidence at those attitudes of the inside tip producing lift as it goes into turbulent Reynolds #'s it seems the efficiency goes up dramatically. And the proof can be seen when they are flying with high performance sailplanes and the hang gliders top out above. One of my favorite things to do in small thermals was to punch the bar out to beyond stall and sit on the core lift at the verge of a spin and just go up. Relative wind was like 90 deg to the wing, basically spinnaker mode. I think this was demonstrated with the Kasper wing quite well.

A few corrections and remarks,
They say that turbulant flow drives diffusion but this is not exclusively true. Molecular diffusion is driven by their own movement within the fluid although this is slower than turbulent mass transport.
It is also mentioned that laminar flow only happens at large scales but remember, this is dependant on the scale but mostly on the viscosity. Plate tectonics in the mantle are described as fluids, spanning some tens of millions of years. With a viscosity of up to 10^20 PaS all of the earth's mantle is in laminar flow. Maybe the largest scale processes happen in turbulant flow but by far the largest 'flowing' mass on earth is in laminar flow.

For many reasons, I find Derek's take on turbulent flow vs laminar flow to be very similar to a comparison often times made in music. At the beginning of the video, he says something on the lines of how laminar flow is pretty and well behaved, whereas turbulent flow can be unpredictable, seemingly messy. I especially find this comparison to also work for classical music as opposed to mainstream music (e.g. pop music). Especially when he uses the quote "If you make the effort, the love you can have for turbulent flow is so much deeper and richer than that superficial fling you have with laminar flow." I loved this quote and I find it applies to the comparison in music, word for word. I love how there are so many similarities between physics and well-structured, yet complex and sometimes unpredictable music.

Us Sailplane Pilots love both types of flow!  Our craft are designed for Laminar flow over and around the surface of our aircraft (boundary layer) so that there's minimal drag and we can fly for long distances without losing much energy or altitude. But to stay aloft we need to find patches of rising air - which are turbulent flow!  ...Although when the wind conditions are just right, the atmosphere forms laminar layers with standing waves over mountains and other terrain features; and these can stack up over incredible heights. Sailplanes have "surfed" these waves to an altitude record of over 72,000 feet (~21950 meters)!!

I know that no particular solution to the Navier-Stokes equations has been found and that it has not been proved that a smooth solution even exists for general starting conditions. However, can we prove that some solution must exist for every valid starting condition, even if we cannot construct such a solution or prove that it is smooth? This would probably have no physical relevance, but it's interesting to think about. The way I see the Millennium Problem defined and the general issue described suggests proving such a solution exists is not too difficult, because otherwise the inclusion of that condition might have been addressed.

2 of my ideals in a single video

I'd like to suggest a small change to the message. Instead of transforming the "ugly duckling" to a "beautiful swan" what if the message was that your worth/loveability is not tied to your beauty?

The tale of the ugly duckling is not actually a great childrens story. And if you look at it the message is quite oppressive. If you don't conform or don't match the societal beauty standard you won't be accepted. And the way to be accepted it offers is to conform to the beauty standard and the norms.

The ugly duckling doesn't need to grow to a beautiful swan. Society needs to learn to accept the ugly duckling as it is.

Now more than ever we need to celebrate diversity. The answer is not tolerance. It is celebration.

I understand that you did not mean to suggest that the "ugly duckling" is not worthy of love but the metaphors we use matter.

And that's why the solution to appreciating turbulent flow should not be seeing it as beautiful. Rather it should be learning to celebrate the chaos and diversity it represents. Learning that things don't need to be beautiful to be worthy.

Also things that are "merely" beautiful are no less valuable than things that are complex. Both things that are and are not beautiful have value in and off themselves. The question of a thingsvalue and the question of it's beauty are and should be kept wholly separate.

I don't mean to attack you but you have a large platform and people look up to you. So the language you use has an outsized impact. So I'd like to ask you consider the language you use to describe the phenomenon as much as I'm sure you consider the correctness of the description itself.

to be fair, i get the love for turbulent flow, it's pretty in a different way than laminar. but i also get the love for laminar.
turbulent is de facto chaotic, so harder to predict. where laminar flow is more predictable and thus easier to work with.
i know we already have formulae for somewhat predicting turbulent flow, but those are often a lot more complex due to the inherent upredictable nature of turbulent flow. whereas laminar is so much easier to predict.
obviously turbulent flow is a lot more prevalent in nature, so learning more about it helps more than learning more about laminar flow.
what i'm saying is....they are both awesome...why not love them equally, kinda like how you should love your children. we all know you have a secret favourite, that's completely normal. yet when anyone asks, you love them equally :P
